docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush returned to work at the White House today after almost 40 hours in Bethesda Naval Hospital, his erratic heartbeat apparently brought under control by two drugs. Mr. Bush vowed to resume his breakneck pace, even though he had experienced some irregularity in his heartbeat early this morning. After more than seven hours of normal beating overnight, Mr. Bush's heart suddenly resumed an irregular rhythm at about 4:45 A.M. today, his doctors said.

headline.main: Heart Controlled, Bush Returns to Work

docs.snippet: President Bush returned to work at the White House today after almost 40 hours in Bethesda Naval Hospital, his erratic heartbeat apparently brought under control by two drugs.   Mr. Bush vowed to resume his breakneck pace, even though he had...

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors found cause for elation and concern today as President Bush's heartbeat finally settled into a normal pattern after two long episodes of atrial fibrillation. The fact that drugs alone could produce and maintain normal rhythm for a number of hours makes it unlikely that the President will need an electrical shock to reset his heart. But the fact that his irregular heart rhythm was unusually resistant to medicines raises the odds that the rhythm will recur and that he will need drug therapy for months, maybe longer.

headline.main: Prognosis for President Concerns Some Doctors

docs.snippet: Doctors found cause for elation and concern today as President Bush's heartbeat finally settled into a normal pattern after two long episodes of atrial fibrillation.   The fact that drugs alone could produce and maintain normal rhythm for a number of...

docs.lead_paragraph: The electrical shock treatment that President Bush's doctors are considering is commonly used to correct irregular heart rhythm when drugs fail. Doctors added a new drug, procainamide, to President Bush's treatment early today, but it has so far failed to correct the irregular heartbeat, or atrial fibrillation.

headline.main: Shock Treatment Common if Drugs Fail
